author: sokani
created_time: December 04, 2024, 07:20:00 PMLast edit: December 04, 2024, 09:15:28 PM by sokani
content: During an interview with Tusker Carlson early this year, president Putin said before the Russia/Ukraine war, that about 80% of Russia foreign trade was in US dollars and Euro. So the sanctions placed by the western countries made Russia to begin to look for ways to circumvent them and Bitcoin was the answer. As we know, recently, president Putin has signed crypto bill into law legalizing Bitcoin mining, as well as crypto taxation. He's also urged BRICS to adopt crypto. Today, during a speech at the world trade center in Moscow, he said nobody can ban Bitcoin. You can watch the video here.We've many topics about Donald Trump on the forum and he's been putting in good words about Bitcoin. With the world leaders, US president-elect Donald Trump and president Vladimir Putin now pro Bitcoin, do you think this would have any effect on mass adoption?

comments.author: Alphakilo
comments.body: He is right, no one can ban Bitcoin the worse that can be done is to regulate it, criminalized it. And times without number we have seen these happen in several countries. Bitcoin if adopted by the BRICS nations it would boost it's adoption world wide. Bitcoin if adopted by the BRICS nations would cause the Dollar to not seem as relevant as it is right now. But this isn't about the dollar but about saving all of our economies. Still bitcoin if adopted with a solid fundamental economies will make us miss the dollar.

comments.body: Another one: things are really getting interesting these days for Bitcoin. comments.author: icalical
comments.body: Putin's move is to decrease dependence on the USD and euro in foreign trade. And Putin legalizing Bitcoin Mining won't instantly encourage Bitcoin mining in Russia, strict regulations, including mandatory reporting and extreme penalties for miners who don't comply to government rules, that could discourage people who wants to start Bitcoin mining in Russia.As for mass adoption, while support from influential people like Trump and Putin could lend more legitimacy to Bitcoin, there are other things to consider, such as regulatory uncertainty and market volatility. Practical use cases and economic conditions will likely more influential than political endorsement in driving adoption.
